Comment: Most mature chess players open with a central Pawn move. The move in and of itself is not bad -- Bird's Opening is a respectable line -- but obviously, you don't expect a child to know the intricacies of offbeat chess openings.

I'm guessing that this youngster had learned about something called a "fianchetto" and because of its exotic name, thought it must be really cool to do. My 6-year-old son often thinks things about games are "cool" even when they worsen his chances, like getting sent back to Start in the game "Sorry!"
Who knows what goes through a child's head? It does protect the Pawn, so in a weird way it has a logic to it.
Completing the fianchetto, and probably feeling like nothing better could happen than to do so.
This one has the rudiments of the idea of development down, anyway.
I'm assuming so as not to spoil the really cool maneuver by blocking the Bishop.
Hey, it is guarded by the Knight. Again, what makes sense to an adult is not necessarily what makes sense to a 5 or 6 year old. I know!
Preparing to attack the White KBP.
Preparing to castle. Presumably the child's instructor had said something about the importance of castling.
Again, i'll have to hazard a guess that at some point the child was told it's agood thing to attack Pawns. This double attacks the KP.
By adult standards, this move is obvious. To a 5-year-old, perhaps they were taught that it's important to open a line for a Rook.
Acting on the basic principle of recapturing.
I can picture the excited squeal of "Check!"
Again, the excitement of checking. Even to me it's a thrill when I launch an attack. To a youngster, they can barely sit still.
No adult would do this, as it blocks in the King. But again, the 5-year-old probably just blocked the check with the first move they saw.
Finis. The father of one of my son's friends in school supplied me with this game. His son was Black, but he wasn't upset by the loss -- he just wanted to play more games.
